2.text: Reach into the candle with a knife, when the candle is burned down to the point where the wax is only 1/4 to 1/3 thick.

3.text: Use a paper towel to wipe out the candle jar.

4.text: Place a dishcloth, folded four ways, into the bottom of a saucepan large enough to hold the jar.

5.text: Fill the jar with room temperature water right to the top so that it overflows.

6.text: Turn on the heat under the pan no higher than medium.

7.text: Check the water temperature using a probe or stick thermometer.

8.text: Use a ladle or small dipper to carefully pour hot water into the full jar, making it overflow into the pan.

9.text: Turn off the heat from the stove, and let the water settle to room temperature.

10.text: Let the remaining wax solidify on the water's surface.

11.text: Pour the remaining water through a sieve and knock the wax chips into the trash.

12.text: Scrub the inside of the jar with a bottle brush and hot, soapy water.

13.text: Place the jar or candle holder in the freezer overnight.

14.text: Take the jar or candle holder out of the freezer the following day.

15.text: Use a knife to pop the wax out in one piece.

16.text: Wash the jar or candle holder in the dishwasher to complete the clean.
